Q14: The ability to generate descriptions should be excellent for people working with both floras and groups of plants. More broadly, having traits in computable and machine "readable" form will be broadly helpful to evolutionary biologists in the long term.
Q9:
Still lacks some completeness and flexibility for some characters.
A few illustrations could be clearer (and larger!)
Word order and a few other details (some punctuation) could be improved in the descriptions generated.
Q10:
Illustrations of characters
Ability to use modifiers for descriptors
Love the ability to generate descriptions

Q6: i didn't use the input templates. your survey won't let me leave that question unanswered
Q14:
I think CR could become an invaluable research tool. Uptake would be enhanced if it provided, (or was integrated with another program that did) a way to store and search specimen data (label data, GIS, links to iNaturalist), and also to store images captured during examination. 

I will need to dissect my specimens while I use CR, so this would be a very convenient time to take images of the dissected parts, and have them linked to the data matrix. This would help me review and revise my work later. It would also make it easy to build a visual key/glossary. If I can store representative images for a particular character trait and state, it will be easier for me to maintain consistency between sessions. e.g., I could store pictures for typical 'acute' vs 'acuminate' scales, to use to remind myself of my own best practices, or to communicate those standards to other team members.

It would also be useful to have a public repository of character matrices, including images and definitions for the different characters. If the first step in a new study is downloading the 'standard' matrix for your group, it would greatly enhance standardization in the field. Allowing users to upload additional characters would help the system grow. You'd probably want to enable some curation, perhaps by taxon groups. i.e., a Carex team could periodically revise and update their standard matrix, based on input from the community.
Q9:
The interface was a bit slow and less responsive than something like Excel. That meant often waiting for a few seconds while entering or updating values. This disrupted momentum when processing my specimen.

It was frustrating to have the interface record values, then erase them after a few seconds - every time I tried to enter '0', the value appeared to be recorded, then after a few seconds it vanished. If I wasn't paying attention, I might not notice that the computer was altering my input.
Q10: Having access to definitions and diagrams of features while I worked was very useful.

Q13: Bugs (ex: using forbidden characters and error message were vague or inexistent), issues while trying to define characters.
Q14: Adding definitions and illustrations to create a complete glossary, making the app faster and more responsive (sometimes delays were unreasonable). Adding more precise characters (which leaf, were to measure). Also, be able to import data from other sources (ex: csv file would make it far easier for other taxonomist to use Character Recorder in their projects.) For example, data could be entered in Excel and then imported in CR. The vocabulary used in the excel spreadsheet could be curated in Character recorder following the ontology and CR could be used to generate species descriptions. As is, there is no way to properly annotate the specimens in CR, so another Excel file is needed for most applications (ex: linking to collector number, date of collection, country, etc.)
Q9:
Bugs that impeded my ability to create new characters slowed me considerably. Sometimes, especially when completing the WERE , To and FROM , I was asked to add whole sentences to the curated vocabulary list, which doesn't make much sense.

Copy paste values from other sources or within the matrix itself. An importation assistant.
Q10: The list of values entered by others while trying to select a character state. The automatic formatting of descriptions, the curated ontology, some illustrations were useful to better define characters. Selecting colors from palette.

Q13: I have limited experience with this feature, as most characters were already present.
Q7: Really none. I found some duplicate values, but these may/probably were the result of my own data-entry errors.
Q14: The illustrated glossary needs to be improved with better illustrations and text (e.g. the width of the pistillate scale is measured at its widest point) that can be expanded. I think better still would be good colour photographs illustrating each feature. Another weak feature is the assessment of colour. The colour chart is currently unhelpful, in my opinion. A CR user cannot quickly match closely the colour of the feature with a colour in the chart. This leads to more subjective assessments of colour with many disparate assessments of colour for the same species/specimen. I'm not sure how this deficiency can be rectified. There may be technology available (e.g. similar to that used in paint stores to assess and match colour swatches) that could be adapted for colour assessment.
Q9: I think I've already addressed the main deficiencies (i.e. illustrations and colour assessment).
Q10: Aside from the noted exceptions, I liked all the features that I used. I would probably benefit from additional working using CR. It's difficult to make a meaningful assessment, as much of my initial exposure to the software involved overcoming the 'learning curve'.

Q13: Some fields are too broad and others are missing. It would seem essential to allow a field to specify which of minimum, maximum, or average we are inputting for each character. It would also be useful to allow specifying how many replicate measurements per specimen we should be doing.
Q7: The difficulties were minor and related to some conventions used by human descriptors for certain special character states that are described in specific and different ways from other character states. A good example is "spike peduncle length 0--3mm", which would be written by a human as "spike sessile, or on peduncle up to 3 mm long"
Q14:
The main selling point of CR is that it fills a niche that is essential to nearly every taxonomist's work, and that is not filled by any other software: recording phenotypic (or other) data at the specimen level. CR could become an essential step in making taxonomic and especially morphometric work more reproduceable. I think that it would be a very misguided to develop CR as a program tailored solely for Carex taxonomists. I can easily envision it becoming THE program that every plant (or even fungal / animal) taxonomists use to record phenotypic data on specimens.


The next critical steps would be to ensure that the structure of CR allows direct linking of recorded data to physical specimens (via fields for collector, collector number and accession number, etc.), and to allow other users to access data recorded by another user on a specimen. This would ensure that CR remains relevant in the emerging framework of the Extended Specimen.

A next step would be to add fields that enable some terms and definitions be taxon-specific, and to allow different standardized character sets depending on which taxon or which project you are working on. This should be controlled by the user. 

For instance, the term "utricle (taxon:Cyperaceae)" would be a deprecated term and an exact synonym of "perigynium (taxon:Cyperaceae)", part of the class "prophyll (taxon:plants)". 

However, the term "utricle (taxon:Amaranthaceae)" would be an accepted term, part of the class "fruit (taxon:plants)".

Another critical step would be to ensure that all the options and fields are available to make character definitions as specific and reproduceable as possible. This means adding more fields to specify which particular structure is measured, in what state, how many replicate measurements are needed.
Q9:
A large part of the negative aspects I noticed during the session was due to badly defined characters chosen as part of the standardized set. I think that a large part of the variation that will be seen across different users during this workshop will come not because of CR per se, but simply because better character definitions should have been chosen from the start.

This is *not* an issue with CR. It is completely fixable and CR seems like a great tool to make character definitions precise and increase consistency and reproducibility of measurements. Adding a few fields to allow character definitions to be more precise will probably be simple. Our main job afterwards will be to come up with character definitions that allow all taxonomically-important variation in Carex to be recorded in a consistent and reproducible manner.
Q10:
Allow multiple character states per character.
Allow multiple specimens to be recorded in parallel.
Asking for definitions for all new terms in the ontology.
Form to ensure that all new characters are precisely defined (although this would need a bit more work)
Standardized character sets that are easy to find when a new matrix is created.
Automated generation of descriptions and matrix export.
Saving characters or remote server.

Q14:
Reasons character recorder may be unlikely to be adopted by _some_ taxonomists:
-some people won't want to be 'forced' to score a standard set of characters, despite the valid rationale for doing so in the broader community. This may be particularly true for some later career people who have had their way of working for several decades. Change is hard!
-perceived lack of flexibility in the system or inadequate training
-uneasiness about how other workers may use 'their' data. Needs to be an explicit data sharing model, attribution guidelines, etc., if the aim is for all workers to be able to see everyone else's data. I admit I don't currently understand how this is structured at present. Perhaps complete sharing of the dataset isn't the aim.

I have realized that this tool would be very useful for my own work, even if, for some reason, I chose not to score every character recommended in the core set (some characters at present are confusing, for example). For example, if I were writing descriptions for species in the Arctic, I am not necessarily interested in the entire range of variation within a species. Instead, I am interested in the range of variation in the species in the geographically defined study area (Arctic plants are sometimes smaller than the same taxon in more southerly locations, for example). 

Critical next steps: 
-the community user group should publish a rationale for the core character set that is recommended. It is obvious why many characters have to be included, but not so obvious why some other characters are included. Users need to understand the value of scoring every character across all taxa, including those that they may not have ever scored before. The latter were the ones that challenged me the most. Examples include 'texture' and some of the leaf sheath characters.
-also publish the ontology showing which terms have been combined, removed, etc. (perhaps this is already done?). New users need to understand all the work that has happened to get to the current point.

-improve the definitions of all terms. Where do the definitions come from (references). Include images that show the character state - multiple images from different sources might be a good approach, though much more work to pull together. Present the character state options in different ways - panel of images, list of text (as it is currently), etc. 

-agreement on how the modifiers/constraints should be used. For example, for a structure that is papillose, my sense is many authors would not distinguish between densely papillose vs. moderately papillose, but they may be inclined to indicate 'scarcely'. How important is consistency in this type of situation? This is currently unclear to users. 

-add a notes field for every sample, and perhaps every character scored for every sample. Taxonomists often want to jot down information relevant to a particular measurement. The best place to do this is

-allow users to upload images of each specimen they have measured, and link the specimen to the sample name. I can see this being very useful, for many reasons.
Q9:
'-see comments in an earlier freeform text box

-lack of clear definitions for all character states so users understand what each terms mean. Another way to do this could be to link to a standard source of terms on the web (not sure if there is a standard, however). 

-lack of definitions for all characters. For example, texture: what are we actually trying to score, tissue structure or pubescence? (I know we have discussed this; I include it just as an example). 

-challenges with clearly describing variation within a particularly character, such as pubescence variation along a long axis. The challenge here may be more with the community agreeing how to approach this than with the software.

-lack of clarity on where exactly to measure a particular character. i.e. which perigynia, which leaf, which inflorescence unit, etc. (this is less a software issue and more an expert-group issue).

-a lot of scrolling required sometimes to see the entire list of character state options. This was sometimes annoying. 

-not sure what to do if a character is absent from a specimen. For example, my specimens did not have anthers, so I could not score them. I left the cells blank. In the future, I may not remember if I simply didn't score those cells for some reason (lack of time) or if the reason was that it was not possible to do so. Ideally, a way to indicate either would be useful. When scoring tens or hundreds of specimens, it's impossible to remember all the details.
Q10:
'-definitions and illustrations, at least when they were present (many lacking)
-standardized approach 
-the ability to auto-generate descriptions - very useful indeed!
-ability to generate statistics of characters - ranges, means, etc.
-uncluttered interface

Q13: I was not always sure what I needed to fill in to complete the process of finishing the definition of a new character.
Q14: I think that CR is likely to be adopted by taxonomists, but only after a few modifications are made. To me, the critical next steps are to: (1) figure out how to simplify the description of variation along a complex structure like scales or leaves where the proximal, apical, and middle portions of the structure may have different features that need to be described; (2) complete an agreed list of characters that is as comprehensive as possible, but not so large that it is burdensome; (i.e., would dissuade persons from using CR, but is a list that requires minimal additions); (3) the use of general figures for things such as shape, apices, pubescence, etc., such that when you are wanted a term the widest variety of terms is visible for comparison when choosing; (4) complete descriptions of terms so that you can confirm that the term that comes to you head at the moment is truly the one you should use (likewise, more figures linked to terms could also help; (5) combine texture and pubescence into a more comprehensive category like vestiture (anything on surface) because often the term desired did not seem to available for use; (6) either order the colors (top down) or create a similar range artificially under the term categories currently used. (7) I think that suggested terms are not limited to one taxon; (8) "Zero" problem (numerical versus words like "sheathless" or "sessile" use of just "absent"; (9) Need for a way for the user to know that a structure is missing from a specimen, for example, all the anthers have fallen off, so they know when a cell is empty it is because it cannot be filled for that specimen; (10) Make sure all the descriptions are clear on where the measurement should always be taken (e.g., always width of widest leaf even is dead or which inflorescence unit should be measured for width and where); (11) "main vein" of leaf and scales cannot be described; (12) for subgenus Carex there is no way to described the characters of the terminal male unit; (13) image of length of perigynium body contradictory; no way to described inflorescence units or the inflorescence in general as androgynous or gynocandrous; (13) Situations where you can have some individuals that may be caespitose to "shortly rhizomatous forming loose mats" - this happens for other characters as well in the sense of when you have gradations, it is not easy to make a complete descriptions of the structure.
Q9: I think that most of the so-called negatives are covered in what I wrote in the things to be done before CR would be adopted by taxonomists, but the complex character descriptions, that is, gradations from one condition to anther over a structure was the most problematic.
Q10: the matrix, the feature that explains clearly how to make the measurement, the export of the excel and description files, automatic mean, extremes (i.e., basic statistics).

Q14:
need more characters - length of basal internode ... and details on measurements - which leaf, fertile or sterile culm, which bract etc. way of dealing with non-measurable or not able to be evaluated, extened version for maximum an minimum values. ... guidance in selection of plant to measure. claification or elimination of some terms (number of total veins and number of distinct veins.

need demonstrations of value or use ... perhaps starting with a complete description of one species in each section   .    to provide keys at the sectional level , to generate hypotheses in relation to other characters. 

make it part of basic student plant systematics training program
Q9: noted above - need more clarification of characters

- explanatory diagrams
- easy to use windows and drop downs

StartDate: Levin's comments
Thanks again for the opportunity to join you at the workshop today. I’m very excited about what you’ve accomplished and hope you are able to move forward with further development.

I found the tool easy to use, but I’m also the kind of person who clicks all the options I can find to see what they do. I think more complete instructions will be important in the future, although the tool seems straightforward enough that they won’t need to be extensive!

In answer to your question of constraining users’ choice of color terms, my experience with FNA leads me to say, “Yes, constrain them!” There are too many examples of people using terms idiosyncratically, thinking that because they understand what they mean, others will, too. Having color charts for all colors like those you already have for brown, green, and red, and similarly binned, will be essential. Despite my caveats about inconsistent screen rendering and the overly precise (RBG) expression of colors when clearly what you’re representing is a range of colors, I think you’ve taken the right approach. Although some users might initially grumble about being constrained, I think most will quickly value the ease of identifying the proper term and the benefits of greater reproducibility and better communication. I also like that you’ve clearly separated brightness, saturation, and luster from hue, and allowed for different forms of multi-coloration.
I also liked the implementation of multiple entry of states for qualitative characters and the rendering of the descriptions with “or”, “sometimes”, and “rarely.”

I think there’s a similar need to find a way to allow multiple entry for quantitative data. For example, leaf length and width usually vary on a single specimen and being able to record more than one value would be helpful. I realize one could do that by treating each leaf as a sample, but that would distort the outcome. One could also enter the manually calculated mean or median value for a specimen, but that would lead to loss of data. Of course, if one also wants to calculate ratios, it would be necessary to associate each length with the proper width. Bottom line: this might be complicated, but I think it is important to explore.

Related to that, I’d love to see a way to include an identifier with each sample. I’d suggest collector, collector number, and herbarium to identify each sample. This works well with what is already standard practice for monographic and revisionary work.

It’s not clear to me with the Carex dataset how surface texture and relief are differentiated. Some of the surface texture terms, for example rough and roughened, are relief as I think of it. Frankly, I’m not sure what surface texture means! I think of texture in the context of the terms listed under internal texture. But perhaps the Carex people think of these differently.
Having a way to import existing data (from a spreadsheet or its csv equivalent) would facilitate future adoption because people could more easily build on work they’ve already done.
I’ll give some more thought to what another test case might be. A few examples come to mind, but I’d like to think about it more. I know I’d love to have a tool for some of my ongoing work!
Best wishes for the rest of the workshop. I’ll be interested to learn about the outcomes.
Jacques' comments
Dear Hong,
Here are some of the characters I want to discuss from the 2 Carex samples.
1: We cannot measure a character more than once with this system
2: Conflict between pubescence on the stem: pubescence or texture. May be use vestiture
3: Abaxial leaf texture: two characters: glabrous on the blade and scabrous on nerves
4: Colour of leaf sheath: OK but how about hyaline which is not a colour
5: Number of staminate flowers: where? including the non terminal staminate spikes? and other spikes with stamens?
6: Length of proximal peduncle: how about if none?
7: Shapes of spikes, perigynia, akenes: ellipsoid instead of elliptic
8: Perigynium beak characters to add:
width of beak at the base
- beak texture1-: - same as the body of perigynium; hardened and of different texture
-beak texture 2: hard or fragile, and soon falling
length of the central opening of the perigynium through the beak (see Carex brunnescens)
9: Presence of vegetative stems or not
10: Vegetative shoots characters: longest leaves, their width
11: Root characters:
pubescence, density
colour of roots
12: Inflorescence rachis vestiture: glabrous, scabrous, papillate
13: Pistillate scales characters:
central band to add: width at the middle, ratio of width vs scale width
central band colour
central band getting or not to the tip of scale
apex if mucronate or aristate: length, texture (glabrous, scabrous)
NB, could apply to some staminate scales
14: Stamen shape of the apex, apex texture: glabrous or spines
15: Perigynium base shape: rounded, cuneate, with ba stipe (length)
16: Passage from the perigynium body to beak: abrupt, gradual
17: Colour of perigynium body, or in different parts
18: Perigynium and akene surface: glossy, lustrous or not
inflorescence bracts: leafy, scaly
inflorescence and spike erect, divergent, pendulous, etc
beak straight or curved
beak tooth length
wall of perigynia thin and fragile, regular or hard to dissect
